About me

About me

Hi! I am Tianze "Leo" Zheng from Beijing, China. I am a second-year master's student at the University of Pennsylvania studying Computer and Information Science. I got my bachelor's degree from the University of Notre Dame in Computer Science and Applied Mathematics double major.

I am a self-motivated software developer with a problem-solving mindset and excellent communication skills. Programming and coding for me is a way to meet the better version of myself, address the issues and make our world a better place, and connect with other interesting people!

I am also a amateur photographer and a street dancer. In my spare time, I enjoy playing video games with friends and playing guitar.

View Resume

Projects

Mini-Minecraft

Mini-Minecraft is a interactive 3D world exploration and alteration program in the Minecraft style implemented by C++ and OpenGL library. I developed features including multi-threading auto-generation of the map, basic funtionalities of the Game Engine, Player Physics, and the camera model, the inventory system, and the day and night cycles.

See Demo Source Code

Mini-Google

Mini-Google is a distributed web search engine that includes the crawler, indexer, PageRank, back-end search engine, and front-end user interface. All of the mini-services are deployed on AWS EC2. The indexer, crawler, and PageRank is implemented using distributed StormLite and MapReduce. The search engine adopts Route Handlers and the Spark Framework to query the search. The UI is developed with ReactJS.

Source Code

Two-Stage Text Summarization Approaches

Reviewed the literature of State-of-the-art text summarization techniques in NLP. I designed a two-stage summarization model to take the use of both summarization approaches: extractive and abstractive model. The two-stage pipeline adopts the output of BERTSumEXT as the gound truth and fine-tuned BART and GPT-2 with BPE tokenizer for better abstractive performance. The fine-tuned pipeline achieves the same ROUGE score as BART (Lewis et al., 2019). Thanks to Prof. Yatskar for his supervision.

See Paper Source Code
